bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, April 3, 1876

div1.p: The Army post expects a visit from Gen. William T. Sherman and the Secretary of War. Reed anticipates his upcoming marriage to Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, April 3, 1876

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
April 3rd 76.

div1.p:
The day
is as uninviting as it could
well be -- rain & hail fall
fast & thick, & notwithstan-
ding this, while I write,
the whole Battallion holds
itself in readiness to march
at a moment's notice- Every
minute we expect to hear
the drums beat off, & then
there will be “hurrying
to and fro--” line will be
formed in an instant,
the music will strike up
and we will be ready
to receive the New Secre-
tary of War & Gen. W. T.
Sherman, the Commander-
in Chief of the U.S. Army.
I almost wish that we may
be disappointed, for, although
I would like to grasp the
hands of so distinguished
visitors, I have no partic-
ular desire to be exposed
to a cold drenching rain
such as is now descending.
We are bound to get soak-
ing wet, as there will be a
grand Review, requiring
at least 3 quarters of an
hour for its performance.
Oh! wouldn't you like to
be a soldier, my little dar-
ling? No umbrellas! Noth-
ing but overcoat & cap to
protect one from the storm.
If not a soldier, my love,
you wouldn't object to be-
ing a soldier's wife, would
you, precious? No! No! and
that you will be! and oh!
the sweetest, dearest little
wife that ever lit up
home with the Sunshine
of her beautiful, bright face!
Oh! how I love to dwell on
this vision! She, who is
now my own, darling Emilie,
will, e're long, be transformed
into my own, sweet little
wife! and still she'll be my
the same dear little Emilie
that she has ever been to
my heart! Ah! I'll plod,
& work -- will meet every ob-
stacle willingly & fearless-
ly -- will be content to wait,
knowing the reward that
awaits me in the near Future;
the love & trust of a pure,
noble woman -- man's best
& greatest Comforter on Earth!
Pardon my brevity, darling, but
as the drums are beating I
must buckle on my sword &
hurry to the Parade-ground-
